Seventh and Eighth-grade students at Iroquois Middle School made lapel pins with red felt poppies, and blue felt cornflowers in French Class. They dedicated each one with the names of Niskayuna alumni veterans as a part of their study of "Le Onze Novembre" (Armistice Day in France/Remembrance Day in Canada).

In France, the bleuet (blue cornflower) is the symbol of memory for, and solidarity with, veterans, victims of war, and orphans, similar to the British and Canadian remembrance poppy. The sale of "bleuet de France" badges on Nov. 11 is used to finance charitable works for those causes!

The remembrance poppy was inspired by the World War I poem, "In Flanders Fields." It's opening lines refer to the many poppies that were the first flowers to grow in the churned-up earth of soldiers' graves.

üåü On Friday, October 18, Mr. Albert Prazniak, his wife, Pat, and their daughter, Jane, took a tour of the high school. Al, now 94-years-old, came to Niskayuna High School in 1959 from Massillon, Ohio, a suburb of Canton, Ohio. He was recruited by the new football coach at that time, the legendary Don Boothe. Together, they built Niskayuna into a football powerhouse. Al taught Social Studies and was the Faculty Manager of Athletics from 1959 to 1972.

During his visit, Al presented a football given to him in 1964, honoring Nisky's first Suburban Football Championship to Larry Gillooley, Director of Physical Education & Athletics, and Niskayuna Football Coach, Brian Grastorf.

Brian and Larry presented him with a coaching shirt and T-shirt, respectively. Al even got to meet the football team before Friday night's game. Welcome back, Mr. Albert Prazniak, it was a pleasure to have you! ü§ó

On Friday, Sept. 27, eight-graders at Iroquois Middle School participated in community service day by volunteering in various community service agencies in the Niskayuna/Schenectady area.

Teachers and parents chaperoned groups of students that were assigned to one community service organization and spent approximately 2 1/2 hours performing volunteer services to assist that agency.

Some of the agencies and volunteer work the students assisted with were:

Van Corlaer Elementary School - Students worked with elementary school children in their classroom studies of science, math,
reading, etc. and utilized the STEAM bus to enhance their learning.

The Regional Food Bank - Students stocked shelves and reorganized the pantry or food supplies for those in need.

Roots and Wisdom - Harvested food to be donated to those in need and cleared the gardens the winter.

Ingersoll Place - Interacted with senior residents and participated in an exercise class and played some games.
